Chapter 7, part 3 on the three kinds of eloquence and wisdom. Thus far, the distinctions of various knowledges have been discussed. The merits accomplished by knowledge will now be revealed.
Among them, the unique qualities of the Buddha are discussed first.
When the Buddha first attained enlightenment and perfected knowledge, he cultivated eighteen kinds of unique qualities of the Buddha.
What are the eighteen?
Verse:
The eighteen unique qualities of the Buddha are the ten powers and so forth.
Discussion:
The ten powers of the Buddha, the four forms of fearlessness, the three forms of unforgetfulness, and great compassion - these combined are called the eighteen unique qualities of the Buddha.
They are cultivated only by the Buddha at the time of perfected knowledge, and are not possessed by other sages, thus they are called unique.
What are the distinctions of the ten powers of the Buddha?
Verse:
The ten powers are the power of place and non-place, the power of action, excluding cessation and the path, eight in number,
The faculty of concentration, the nine liberations, the nine spheres of mastery, the ten universal bases,
The knowledge of past lives, death and rebirth, and worldly knowledge, are either six or ten knowledges.
The knowledge of past lives and death and rebirth are based on the dhyanas, the others are universal.
In Jambudvipa, male, in the Buddha's body, unobstructed with regard to objects.
The treatise says:
The ten powers of the Buddha are: the power of knowledge of proper and improper, which is by nature the ten knowledges of the Tathagata.
On what basis are these powers established?
The Buddha himself said in the sutras:

Bhiká¹£us, listen carefully. The TathÄgata truly knows what is proper as proper, and what is improper as improper, and so on at length.ğŸ”½Knowing that the nature and function of all dharmas definitely exist is called the knowledge of what is proper.
Knowing that the nature and function of all dharmas definitely do not exist is called the knowledge of what is improper.

This knowledge universally takes sentient beings and insentient objects as its object, and is not in contradiction with any of the other knowledges. Fearing that it would be difficult to understand with just a brief explanation and little effort, he therefore further analyzes out the remaining nine knowledges here, as extensively distinguished by the Blessed One in the Sutra on the Many Realms himself.
Evil bodily and other actions definitely have the possibility of producing unloved results, but there is definitely no possibility of producing loved results, and so on at length.
What is not explained in that sutra, I rely on other teachings to further briefly distinguish.

Namely, it is definitely impossible for the Tathagatas to still have errors and mistakes, to give one-sided answers to questions that should be analyzed, to lack power and fearlessness, the three types of mindfulness, and so on, and the unique qualities.
It is definitely impossible for the sages to still give rise to the afflictions eliminated by the path of seeing, to cover up their faults, and to fall into evil rebirths.

One who commits the uninterrupted [karmas] sees the Dharma in the present body, one who falls into wrong nature enters right nature in the present, there are true Å›ramaá¹‡as within the teachings of non-Buddhists, there are those who take rebirth but do not die, there are non-returners who are reborn in the desire realm, there are arhats who take rebirth again, there are those who abandon the two kinds of consciousness yet still engage in activity, there are thirteen abodes, nineteen elements, a sixth aggregate, a fourth time, and a fifth truth, and it is impossible that these do not exist.
It is possible to obstruct what the TathÄgata sends, and the Blessed One's emissaries have not yet completed their task.

It is possible to harm one who is in the concentration of loving-kindness or the concentration of cessation, a practitioner following faith or the teachings, one in Uttarakuru, one who falls into evil destinies, and one who dies prematurely, but it is impossible that these do not exist.

The noncessation of conditioned forces and the noneternality of nirvana, the possibility of ordinary beings severing the passions of the peak of existence, the simultaneous occurrence of two minds in a single stream of consciousness, the attraction of a ripened effect by a pure cause, the possibility of the five sense consciousnesses being associated with the factors of enlightenment, the existence of birth and death in the state of dreamless sleep, the possibility of retrogressing from the fruit of a holy path and obtaining it again, are all impossible.

The five consciousnesses are devoid of applied and sustained thought, have as objects that which is past and present, and are devoid of an external realm of objects. There is olfactory and gustatory consciousness, and there is morally neutral consciousness that covers over and obscures. There is one who is born in a higher realm and enters into contemplation. There is the ear that sees visible forms and the eye that hears sounds, and the tongue that smells fragrances, etc. All of these are impossible.
These and other similar kinds of things are called impossible. The opposite of these are all called possible.

Isnâ€™t it true that knowledge of the possible already knows the impossible, and that knowledge of the impossible already knows the possible? Why bother to speak of both the possible and the impossible?

Although this is really the case, still the two are spoken of together in order to refute the theory of no cause and in order to refute the theory of bad causes. There is no error in speaking of the two in relation to the one substance of knowledge.
How do we know that in the power of knowledge of bases and nonbases, the other nine powers are extracted from it? Because all the others have the meaning of this power.
That is, it is definitely not the case that bad conduct can produce a desirable retribution, and that good conduct can produce an undesirable retribution.
It is definitely the case that the opposite is true.

Also, it is definitely not the case that a samÄdhi that is conducive to retrogression can attain superior qualities, and that a samÄdhi that is conducive to progress can cause one to retrogress and fall.
It is definitely the case that the opposite is true.
Also, it is definitely not the case that if the faculties of a certain stage can realize a certain fruit, then the faculties are not yet complete and one has already realized the fruit of that stage.
It is definitely the case that the opposite is true.
They also know that it is impossible for those with inferior resolve, contemptible joy and pleasure, to attain superior virtues, but that it is definitely possible for the opposite to be so.

They also know that it is impossible for the various types of sentient beings, with their different natures, to be in accord with each other, but that it is definitely possible for the opposite to be so.

They also know that it is impossible for those who pursue the practice of birth and death to realize nirvÄá¹‡a, or for those who pursue the practice of nirvÄá¹‡a to bring about birth and death, but that it is definitely possible for the opposite to be so.
They also know that it is impossible for the past to have a beginning, but that it is definitely possible for the opposite to be so.

They also know that it is impossible for those who have not severed the bonds of birth to be reborn after death, or for those who have already been reborn to never die, or for them not to go to good or evil destinies, but that it is definitely possible for the opposite to be so.
They also know that it is impossible for improper attention to be able to attain the exhaustion of contaminants, but that it is definitely possible for the opposite to be so.
It is certain that the opposite of this is possible.

I have briefly indicated the scope of each of these powers in order to show what is possible and what is impossible. If I were to discuss the matter in its entirety, my discussion would be endless. Therefore, all of these powers should be called powers of what is possible and what is impossible. But I fear that if I were to do this, it would be difficult to understand, and so I have established different names for them.
The second power is the power of knowledge of the retribution of actions, which is by nature the eight knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation and the knowledge of the path.

That is, the unobstructed knowledge that well distinguishes the retribution of various kinds of actions in the form of various kinds of results of retribution is called the power of knowledge of the retribution of actions.

Or it is said to be the power of knowledge of oneâ€™s own actions, that is, the unobstructed knowledge that well distinguishes the kind of result that is acquired by the power of oneâ€™s own actions and that cannot be given or taken away by wife, children, etc.

The unobstructed knowledge that well distinguishes the kind of action that necessarily acquires oneâ€™s own result and that cannot be bartered for any other result is called the power of knowledge of oneâ€™s own actions.
Also, the Buddha himself explained the characteristics of this power, saying:

Monks, listen attentively. The Buddha knows, in accordance with reality, the various places, causes, events, and fruits of the past, future, and present karmic dharmas and their experiences, and so on in detail.
There are three kinds of karmic dharmas and four kinds of karmic experiences. Because of the karmic dharmas, they are called karmic dharmas.
Karmic experiences are either the dharmas of karma, thus they are called karmic dharmas, which is the meaning of the categories of various karmas.
This shows that the TathÄgata can know in accordance with reality the various categories of karmas in the past, etc., the differences in places, etc., and the fruits that are experienced.
Among them, various places means different locations. Knowing that such karma is created in a certain place, this karma will mature in a certain place.
That is to say, knowing that this karma is created in the heavens, etc., this karma will mature in the human realm, etc. This is called knowing in accordance with reality the various places.

As for distinct causes, distinct conditions are meant. One knows that such and such an action encounters these conditions to mature, or one knows that this action is created by these conditions. This is called truly knowing the distinct causes.
As for distinct things, distinct objects are meant. One knows that such and such an action, when it reaches the time of maturity, has the power to attract distinct objects such as form, etc.

Or one directly knows that the nature of action itself is not the same. This is called knowing distinct things. One knows that this action has the nature of this object, but it is not so for the others. This is called truly knowing the distinct things.

As for distinct fruits, distinct retributions are meant. One knows that such and such an action definitely produces a retribution fruit, and this action is indefinite in producing a retribution. This action's retribution passes through such and such a period of time, and there are those that do not. This action's retribution still has remainder and no remainder. In this way, etc., the distinctions in retribution are extremely subtle and difficult to understand, yet one is able to understand them. This is called truly knowing the distinct fruits.

The power of knowledge of the various superior and inferior faculties, the power of knowledge of the various dispositions, and the power of knowledge of the path that leads everywhere, these four powers are all of the nature of nine knowledges, excluding the knowledge of cessation.

That is to say, to know the nature of the various meditations, etc., is called attainment. The unobstructed knowledge of the methods of cultivation, the flavors, purity, and impurity of the various meditations, etc., as well as the knowledge of the various stages of regression, abiding, progress, and decisive distinction, is called the power of knowledge of the various meditations, etc.
Moreover, the Buddha himself explained the characteristics of these powers, saying:
Bhiká¹£us, listen carefully. The Buddha truly knows the defilements, purity, and establishment of the various meditations, liberations, samÄdhis, and samÄpattis, and so on, in detail.
The characteristics of the various meditations, etc., will be discussed in the chapter on samÄdhi.

Defilement refers to that which obstructs the realization of the various meditations, etc. Purity refers to the purity of these various dharmas. The abiding of the various pure dharmas is called establishment.
Or, the stage of regression is called defilement, the stage of progress and the stage of penetrating insight are called purity, and the stage of abiding is called establishment.

If one truly knows the differences in the faculties of sentient beings that can attain superior virtues without obstructed cognition, it is called the power of the cognition of the higher and lower faculties.
Moreover, the Buddha himself explained the characteristics of this power, saying:
Bhiká¹£us, listen carefully. The Buddha truly knows the higher and lower faculties of sentient beings, and so on, in detail.
This shows that the Buddha knows the superior and inferior faculties of sentient beings without error.
Although there are middling faculties, they depend on superior and inferior faculties, and are included in inferior and superior faculties, so they are not separately shown.
What is the meaning of the term faculty in this context?
It refers to faith and so on. Even in the general continuity of those who have severed wholesome roots, there are past and future wholesome dharmas such as faith.
Or it refers to the mind faculty and so on.
If one truly knows the differences in the joys and pleasures of sentient beings without obstructed cognition, it is called the power of the cognition of various inclinations.
Moreover, the Buddha himself explained the characteristics of this power, saying:
Bhiká¹£us, listen carefully. The Buddha knows as it truly is the various inclinations of sentient beings, and so on, and so forth.
This shows that the Buddha knows the various kinds of preferences and distinctions of sentient beings, because preferences and inclinations are different names.

If one truly knows the various kinds of sentient beings, the dispositions, inclinations, and latent tendencies formed through countless practices since beginningless time in the past, and the various distinctions in the nature of dharmas, the unobstructed cognition is called the power of knowing the various kinds of realms.
Moreover, the Buddha himself explained the characteristics of this power, saying:
Bhiká¹£us, listen carefully. The Buddha knows as it truly is the various realms and non-one realm in the world, and so on, and so forth.
Various realms shows the meaning of each being separate. Non-one realm shows the meaning of being numerous.
One should know that in this context, realm, disposition, latent tendencies, and nature of dharmas are different names.
These four powers all take conditioned [dharmas] as objects, so among the ten knowledges, they only include nine knowledges.
Seventh is the power of knowledge of the various paths and their respective destinations.
Or the term path indicates two meanings. If it only means the paths that lead to various destinations, then this power is comprised of nine knowledges excluding the knowledge of cessation.
If it also means the destinations to which the paths lead, then it is comprised of the ten knowledges.

That is, the Buddha's unobstructed knowledge of the causes and effects of birth and death, and of the path to their cessation, is called the power of knowledge of the various paths and their respective destinations.
Moreover, the Buddha himself explained the characteristics of this power, saying:
Bhiká¹£us, listen well! The Buddha knows all the various paths and their destinations as they truly are, and so on, and so forth.
This means that the Buddha can truly know the paths that lead to birth and death and the paths that lead to nirvÄá¹‡a.
Among the paths that lead to birth and death, there are paths leading to the hells up to paths leading to the heavens. Within each of these there are many kinds.

The paths that lead to nirvÄá¹‡a are distinguished by the three vehicles. Within each of these there are also many kinds. Based on the general statement, they are called the various paths and their respective destinations.

The eighth power, that of the knowledge of the recollection of past abodes, and the ninth power, that of the knowledge of the future destinies of beings, are both by nature conventional knowledge. These two powers are distinguished by their characteristics.
That is, the power of the knowledge of the recollection of past abodes is the unobstructed knowledge that truly knows the differences in the past abodes of oneself and others.
The power of the knowledge of future destinies of beings is the unobstructed knowledge that truly knows the future destinies of beings.
Also, the Buddha himself has explained the characteristics of these two powers.
He said, â€œMonks, listen carefully. The Buddha, in the past, in various abodes, in one life, in two lives, and so on, extensively explains.
The Buddha, with the pure heavenly eye, surpassing that of humans, sees all sentient beings, and so on, extensively explains.
The extensive explanation of these two is like that in the section on the six supernormal knowledges.
The tenth power is the power of the knowledge of the destruction of the contaminants.

The word â€œalsoâ€ in the verse indicates that there are two interpretations of the meaning. If it is said that it only takes the destruction of the contaminants as its object, then it is composed of six knowledges, excluding the knowledge of the path, the knowledge of suffering and its cause, and the knowledge of othersâ€™ minds.
If it is said that it also takes the means to the destruction of the contaminants as its object, then it is composed of ten knowledges.

Reason requires that it be so, because in the chapter on the characteristics of the knowledges, it says that the knowledge of the extinction of contamination and the knowledge of the path that leads to its extinction are both called the power of the knowledge of the extinction of contamination.
Also, the Buddha himself explained the characteristics of this power, saying:

â€œBhiká¹£us, listen carefully! Because the Buddha has extinguished contamination, he has liberated his mind and cognition through the extinction of contamination. He has realized and personally accomplished it, and he has realized and personally accomplished the knowledge that his birth has ended, and so on at length.â€

These last three powers are the three supernormal knowledges, because these three among the six supernormal knowledges are superior and are established as the three illuminations in the state of no-more-learning. In the body of the TathÄgata, they are also called powers.

Although the supernormal knowledge of the divine eye and the supernormal knowledge of the divine ear exist in the body of the Buddha, they are not of great use, and therefore they are not called powers.

For example, the divine eye can see the differences in the retribution of good and evil destinies of sentient beings, and because of this, it can induce the arising of superior knowledge. It also correctly understands the karma that can bring about that retribution. Because of this, it is established as the name of the supernormal knowledge of death and rebirth.
The supernormal knowledge of the divine eye and the divine ear do not have this great function, and therefore the other two are not established as powers.

However, the power of knowing the minds of others is not separately mentioned, because its meaning is already included in the powers of knowing the faculties, etc., because in the faculties, etc., of others there are minds and mental factors.

Moreover, the Blessed One is endowed with omniscience, and he also has mastery over crafts, treatises, etc., but in the Buddha's work, this much has already been accomplished. Other knowledges do not have a separate superior function in this regard, and therefore, although he has them, they are not separately mentioned.
He relies only on the universal awakening to the ten kinds of knowables, because what the Buddha should do is all completely fulfilled in this.
What are called the ten kinds of knowables?

They are the meaning of causes and non-causes among all dharmas, the various distinctions of the results of karma that are scattered in many places, the different kinds of virtues in the stages of concentration, the differences in the faculties, dispositions, and natures of sentient beings to be converted, the distinctions of causes and effects in terms of what is to be eliminated and its antidotes, the differences in the experiences of the past and future, and the differences in the skillful means of being free from defilements and not continuing [in cyclic existence].
But when this matter is understood, the other matters, even if they exist, are of no benefit or harm. Therefore only the ten are called powers.
Moreover, when a Buddha observes sentient beings to be converted, he teaches them in accordance with their capacities, and only ten knowledges are necessary.
That is, by means of the first knowledge, he observes sentient beings to be converted and knows the differences in their capacities for the vehicles.
By means of the second knowledge, he observes sentient beings to be converted and knows the differences in their karmic obstacles in their life streams.

By means of the third knowledge, he observes sentient beings to be converted and knows the differences in their attachment to the flavors of the meditations, etc., and the differences in the heaviness or lightness of their obstacles of the passions. Knowing these two causes, he also knows the obstacles to retribution.
By means of the fourth knowledge, he observes sentient beings to be converted and knows the differences in their capacities for the pure category.
By means of the fifth knowledge, he observes sentient beings to be converted and knows the differences in their practices in the category of the pure category.
By means of the sixth knowledge, he observes sentient beings to be converted and knows the differences in their natures in the category of the pure category.
The seventh knowledge observes the various benefits and harms of the activities of those to be converted and correctly contemplates the cultivation of cessation.
The eighth knowledge observes the various accumulations of those to be converted in the past.
The ninth knowledge observes the various births of those to be converted in the future.
The tenth knowledge observes the various means of attaining liberation by those to be converted.
If any one of these ten knowledges is lacking, then the work of converting sentient beings is not complete, and much is useless. Therefore they are neither increased nor decreased.
The specific characteristics have already been explained.

As for the distinction of stages, the eighth and ninth are based on the four meditations, while the other eight are generally based on eleven stages, namely the desire realm, the four meditations, the intermediate state, and the four formless realms, which are called the eleven stages. The stages of various superior virtues are generally just these.
The distinction of stages has already been explained.
As for the distinction of bodies, they are all based on the male body of JambudvÄ«pa, because only this is suitable as the basis of power.
The two vehicles also have these ten knowledges, so why are they only called powers in a Buddha?
The name power is given to them because they are unimpeded. The knowledge of a Buddha is unimpeded with regard to objects and is therefore called a power.

The others are not so, because the two vehicles are still unable to see the seeds of liberation in the life streams of sentient beings, much less be able to know the other profound and subtle matters.
For example, ÅšÄriputra abandoned a person who sought to cross over, and was unable to observe and know the number of lives of a pigeon being chased by a hawk in the past and future.
MahÄmaudgalyÄyana was unable to observe and see the differences in ghosts attracted by the wind of karma.

Therefore, the two vehicles, the supernormal knowledge of the heavenly eye, etc., observing the distance of the realms, is different from that of a Buddha. Because it is not unimpeded, it is not called a power.
The two vehicles and a Buddha are the same in the extinction of contamination. Why is the knowledge of a Buddha alone called a power?
Only the World Honored One has the knowledge that thoroughly penetrates the characteristics of the extinction of all contaminations of sentient beings.

The Bhagavat is unobstructed in regard to the knowledge of the various categories of the extinction of all the passions of all sentient beings, but the two vehicles are not like this. Therefore, the name power belongs only to the Buddha.
Also, only the Buddha has the power of wisdom, because his wisdom is sharp.
How is it sharp?
The power of the Buddhaâ€™s wisdom can quickly eliminate the passions and their instincts, just as a strong person wielding a sharp knife cuts through grass, etc.
The aggregates of all sentient beings are the same in appearance. How does the Buddha see that there are various realms?
Even though the aggregates of all sentient beings are the same in appearance, there are still differences among them.

That is, even though the substance of those aggregates is not different, there are innumerable categories that are not the same. The Buddha knows them all as they are, and he is totally unobstructed. Therefore the World Honored One acquires the power of knowledge of the various realms.
Or, the fame of the TathÄgatas is lofty and distant, and their wisdom and marvelous functions are rare and boundless. Only the Buddha can know them; they cannot be measured by others.
Why is it strange that the TathÄgata can know the specific characteristics in the absence of specific characteristics in other understandings?
Having explained the extent of the power of the Buddha's mind, we should now explain the power of the body attained by the Bodhisattva.
A verse says:
The body has the power of NÄrÄyaá¹‡a, or each joint has it,
Seventy times the power of an elephant, etc., and it is by nature the basis of touch.
The treatise says:
The power of the Buddha's physical body is equal to that of NÄrÄyaá¹‡a.
Other masters say:
Each joint of the Buddha's body has the power of NÄrÄyaá¹‡a.
In reality, the power of the Buddha's body is boundless, just like the power of the mind, because it can uphold the great merit of unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.

The joints of the body of the Great Awakened One, the Solitary Awakened One, and the Wheel-Turning King are connected in sequence, resembling a coiled dragon, and the joints are connected like a chain. Therefore, the three are superior and inferior in power.
What is the measure of the power of NÄrÄyaá¹‡a?
The seven powers of the elephant, etc., increase ten times each.
Namely, ordinary elephants, fragrant elephants, MahÄnÄga, PÄlaka, VÄraá¹‡agha, and NÄrÄyaá¹‡a, each subsequent one's strength is ten times that of the previous.
Some say:
The first sixty increase tenfold, equal to half the strength of NÄrÄyaá¹‡a, and this strength, doubled, forms NÄrÄyaá¹‡a.
Other masters say:
This measure is equal to the strength of a thousand Airavaá¹‡a celestial elephants.
What is the measure of this celestial elephant's strength?
When the Thirty-three Celestials are about to play in the garden, the celestial elephant knows and transforms into various heads, adorned in various ways, and goes to the celestial palace.
The celestial retinue numbers in the many thousands, riding it through the sky like a birch leaf, quickly arriving at the pleasure garden to enjoy themselves as they wish.
The celestial elephant's strength is like this. A thousand times this strength is equal to NÄrÄyaá¹‡a.
Among all the explanations, only the latter is reasonable.
The power of the body is by nature the sense base of touch. This should be a general classification of the various kinds of touch.
Some say:
It is only a distinction of the great elements.
Some say:
It is a derivative of touch, separate from the seven.
Some say:
Power is heavy, and weakness is light.
This is called the power of the Buddha's physical body.
What are the distinctions in the characteristics of the Buddha's four forms of fearlessness?
A verse says:
The four forms of fearlessness are in order the first, twelfth, and seventh powers.
The treatise says:
The Buddha's four forms of fearlessness are as extensively explained in the sutras. The first fearlessness of perfect enlightenment has the nature of ten knowledges, just like the first power.
The second fearlessness of the complete destruction of defilements has the nature of sixty knowledges, like the tenth power.
The third fearlessness of proclaiming the obstacles to dharmas has the nature of eight knowledges, like the second power.
The fourth fearlessness of proclaiming the path to liberation has the nature of nine or ten knowledges, like the seventh power.
Why do the Buddhas have only four forms of fearlessness?
But it is just on the basis of these four that the Buddha, the World-honored One, is said to have perfected his own and othersâ€™ virtues.

The first fearlessness shows that the Buddha, the World-honored One, has perfected his own knowledge, and the second fearlessness shows that the Buddha has perfected his own elimination of passions. These two show that the Buddha has perfected his own virtue of benefiting himself. In order to show that the World-honored One has perfected his virtue of benefiting others, he therefore again speaks the last two fearlessnesses.
The third fearlessness prevents one from traveling on a false path, and the fourth fearlessness makes one travel on the true path.

That is, the Buddha, in various places, speaks of obstacles for his disciples and makes them eliminate them, which is to say that he makes them cultivate the means of perfecting the virtue of elimination.

Also, in various places he speaks of the path of liberation for his disciples and makes them practice it correctly, which is to say that he makes them cultivate the means of perfecting the virtue of knowledge.
These two show that the Buddha has perfected his virtue of benefiting others.

It is just on the basis of these four that, as the case may be, the Buddha is said to have perfected his own and othersâ€™ virtues of knowledge and elimination to the ultimate point, and therefore only four are established.
How can it be said that fearlessness is knowledge? It should be said that fearlessness is accomplished by knowledge.
In reality, it should be so, but in order to show that fearlessness is the proximate cause of wisdom, therefore the essence of fearlessness is established in terms of wisdom.
As for fearlessness, it means not being timid or fearful. Because one has wisdom, one is not timid or fearful of others, therefore wisdom can be the causal nature of fearlessness.

Only the four wondrous knowledges of the Buddha are the causes of the four fearlessnesses. The wondrous knowledge of all dharmas and all characteristics of the TathÄgatas is the cause of the first fearlessness.
The wondrous knowledge of the TathÄgatas' elimination of all afflictions and habitual tendencies is the cause of the second fearlessness.

Only our World-Honored One, because he possesses this, is not displeased by slander, not delighted by praise, always benefits even when constantly opposed, deeply sympathizes even when cut and stabbed, is not arrogant even with extraordinary assistants, supernatural powers, wisdom, and skills, does not give rise to anger and resentment even when turning away from desires, and does not give rise to biased affection and love even when closely attending to pleasures.

Although they practice subduing and disciplining, they do not seek to be assisted. Although they practice reprimanding, they do not wish for disharmony. Although they temporarily expel, they do not use harsh words. Although they permanently expel, they do not allow them to fall into error.

Although they are fearless, they are not coarse or rough. Although they always have affection, they do not give rise to craving. Although they manifest their own virtues, they do not pursue fame and profit. Although they manifest others' faults, they do not cause shame or humiliation. Although they gather disciples, they do not form their own faction. Although they reprimand evil companions, they do not destroy others' groups. If clans and those with aspirations come to associate with them, they only show the correct Dharma and do not socialize with them. All of this is due to the wonderful wisdom of ending outflows, so this wonderful wisdom is the second cause.
If the Tathagatas know their disciples' gains and benefits with wonderful wisdom, it is the cause of the last two forms of fearlessness.

Or the essence of fearlessness is precisely the four kinds of wonderful wisdom. Fear is called fear. It means having fear due to not fully understanding the Dharma. Wisdom has the ability to directly treat this fear. Because it is contrary to fear, it is called fearlessness.
Is it not the case that the absence of knowledge is not the substance of fear? How can you say that the substance of knowledge is the same as fearlessness?
This criticism is unreasonable, because knowledge is the proximate antidote of many dharmas, just as it is the absence of doubt.
That is, just as knowledge is the proximate antidote of ignorance, it also has the power to be the proximate antidote of fear, and therefore it is called knowledge and also fearlessness.
Just as the antidote of ignorance is also able to be the antidote of doubt, and therefore it is called knowledge and also certainty.

Although the object to be eliminated, ignorance, is not doubt, the names knowledge and absence of doubt have the same substance. In the same way, although ignorance is different from fear, the name fearlessness directly refers to the substance of knowledge, because one good dharma is able to eliminate many bad dharmas.
Some say:
Ignorance also includes the substance of fear.
Therefore, in this case, one should not raise objections.
What is the difference between power and fearlessness?

There is no difference, because their substance is the same as knowledge. However, the meaning of power is distinguished from the substance of knowledge, and fearlessness is established based on a different meaning.

The causes of not being subdued are called powers, and the causes of not being frightened are called fearlessnesses.ğŸ”½Or, the initial establishment is called power, and the non-movement after establishment is called fearlessness.
Or, not being subdued by others is called power, and being able to subdue others is called fearlessness.
Other masters say:
It is like a good doctor who thoroughly understands medical methods being called power, and skillfully curing various illnesses being called fearlessness.
Some say:
Being brave is called power, and being courageous and not cowardly is called fearlessness.
These two kinds also have different meanings. The meaning of accomplishing things is the meaning of power, and the meaning of not being timid is the meaning of fearlessness.
What are the characteristics of the Buddha's three establishments of mindfulness?
Verse:

Treatise:
The Buddha's three establishments of mindfulness are extensively explained in the sutras.

When the disciples are all respectful and practice correctly, the TathÄgata, in relation to them, does not give rise to joy, but abandons and abides in right mindfulness and right knowledge. How are the great compassion of the Buddhas distinguished?
Verse:
Great compassion is only conventional knowledge, with provisions, aspects, objects,
Equality, superior grade, therefore different from compassion due to eight causes.
Treatise:
The great compassion of the TathÄgata is by nature conventional knowledge, universally taking as its object all sentient beings, because it takes as its objects the three kinds of suffering, etc.
Pure knowledge does not have this kind of object. On the basis of what meaning is the name great compassion established?
It is established on the basis of five meanings.
First, it is called great because it is based on a great accumulation of merit and knowledge, because it is accomplished by a great accumulation of merit and knowledge.
Second, it is called great because its aspects are great, because it is able to take as its objects the three kinds of suffering.
Third, it is called great because its object is great, because it universally takes as its objects sentient beings of the three realms.
Fourth, it is called great because it is impartial, because it equally benefits and gladdens all sentient beings.
Fifth, it is called great because it is superior, because there is no other compassion that can equal it.
Other masters say:

It is called great compassion because it is realized through great effort, because it is accomplished by the body of a great being, because it enters the ranks of the great jewels of merit, and because it can save beings from great suffering.
What is the difference between compassion and great compassion?
There are eight kinds of differences between these two.
The first is a difference in essence, because the essence of compassion is absence of hatred and the essence of great compassion is absence of delusion.
The second is a difference in the body in which it is realized, because compassion is realized in the body of a bodhisattva and great compassion is realized only in the body of a Buddha.

The third is a difference in mode of activity, because compassion has as its mode of activity the suffering of the first truth, and great compassion has as its mode of activity the three kinds of suffering.
The fourth is a difference in objects, because compassion has as its object the desire realm and great compassion has as its object the three realms.
The fifth is a difference in stages, because compassion is realized in the fourth trance state and great compassion is realized in the other three trances.

The sixth is a difference in the state of detachment, because compassion is realized in the state of detachment from the peak of existence and great compassion is realized in the state of detachment from the summit of existence.
Moreover, compassion is realized at the time of detachment from the desire realm, and great compassion is realized only at the time of detachment from the desire realm.
The seventh is a difference in the act of saving, because compassion is the desire to save and great compassion is the act of saving.
The eighth is due to compassion, because compassion is different in being equal or unequal.

Those who are wise should reflect on the three kinds of perfect virtues of the TathÄgata and give rise to deep reverence.
What are the three?
First, the virtue of the perfection of causes; second, the virtue of the perfection of effects; and third, the virtue of the perfection of benefits.

The first, the virtue of the perfection of causes, is also of four kinds. First, cultivation without remainder, because the two kinds of provisions of merit and knowledge are cultivated without omission.ğŸ”½Second, cultivation for a long time, because cultivation lasts for three incalculable eons without weariness.
Third, uninterrupted cultivation, because diligent and vigorous cultivation is uninterrupted moment by moment.
The fourth is the virtue of cultivation with respect, which is the cultivation of not being heedless due to being respectful of what is to be learned and not being arrogant.
Next, the virtue of perfect fruition also has four kinds: the virtue of wisdom, the virtue of severance, the virtue of power, and the virtue of the physical body.
The virtue of wisdom has four kinds: the wisdom without a teacher, the wisdom of everything, the wisdom of all aspects, and the effortless wisdom.
The virtue of severance has four kinds: the severance of all afflictions, the severance of all obstacles to samÄdhi, the ultimate severance, and the severance together with the propensities.

The virtue of power has four kinds: the power of mastery over transforming, changing, and sustaining external objects, the power of mastery over shortening or extending one's lifespan, the power of mastery over making empty obstacles, extremely distant places, and rapid movement, and small things entering large ones, and the power of causing the various inherent natures of the world to turn into superior and wondrous things.

The perfection of power is also fourfold: one is able to convert those who are difficult to convert; one is able to resolve doubts when questioned; one is able to establish teachings that will endure; and one is able to subdue evil forces.

The perfection of physical body is also fourfold: one is endowed with the major and minor marks; one is endowed with the marks of excellence; one is endowed with great power; and the bones of oneâ€™s body are stronger than diamond and oneâ€™s physical radiance surpasses that of a hundred thousand suns.

The perfection of benefit is also fourfold: one causes sentient beings to be eternally liberated from the three evil destinies and from birth and death, and one causes them to be established in the good destinies and in the three vehicles.

The above is a general description of the perfections of the TathÄgata. If we analyze them in detail, they are infinite in number. Only the Buddha, the World-Honored One, can know and explain them. If he were to remain in the world for many incalculably long eons, speaking about them, he would still not be able to exhaust the subject.
This shows that the body of the Buddha, the World-Honored One, is endowed with infinite, supreme, wondrous, and special causes, effects, and benefits, like a great mountain of jewels.
There are foolish people who lack many virtues themselves. Even if they hear such a mountain of the Buddha's merits and the Dharma he expounds, they are unable to believe and revere it.

Those who are wise, upon hearing such teachings, give rise to a mind of faith and reverence that penetrates to the bone marrow. As for the three qualities shared with other noble ones, what is non-contention?
The verse says:
Non-contention is a conventional cognition, unmoving in the fourth meditative absorption,
In the three continents, conditioned by what has not yet arisen, desires and afflictions in the desire realm.
The treatise says:

Arhats remember many past lives in which they experienced various kinds of bodies, and they give rise to the passions of themselves and others. Because of this, they continue to experience unpleasant results. They then think,
If a body with passions gives rise to passions when it is their object, it still attracts the result of suffering, much more so if it is a body free from passions and endowed with superior qualities.

Having thought this, they generate this kind of knowledge of the aspects of the truths. By this means, they cause other sentient beings not to give rise to craving and hatred in regard to their bodies.

All of these are by nature conventional knowledge, because they take as objects the passions of others that are to be eliminated by cultivation in the future. They do not take this as their mode of activity.
If the substance of noncontentiousness is categorized as knowledge, how does one cultivate the samÄdhi of noncontentiousness?

This is not contradictory, because in a single class of thought there are many merits, and one speaks of it according to one of them, just as a single mountain has many things and one speaks of it according to one of them.
It must be that noncontentiousness is categorized as knowledge, because it is skillful means that precedes the matter of protecting the future passions of the mental continuities of others.
However, all disputes are generally of three kinds, because of the differences of aggregates, speech, and passions.
The dispute of aggregates is death; the dispute of speech is fighting; the dispute of passions is the one hundred and eight passions.
Because of this, the power of conventional knowledge is able to stop the dispute of passions, and for that reason it is called absence of dispute.
This knowledge only takes the fourth trance as its support, because it opposes the cause of suffering, and because the path of ease in the fourth trance is the most superior.
The result of non-movement can produce it, and not others. If others cannot prevent the arising of their own passions, how much less can they stop the passions of anotherâ€™s body.

It is concerned with the passions of the desire realm that have not yet arisen, and it prevents the arising of passions in others, so that others will not generate passions in regard to oneself.
As for the passions that are not concerned with things, it is impossible to prevent their arising, because they arise internally and are able to be generally concerned with objects as is appropriate.
We have finished discussing absence of dispute.
What is knowledge of vows?
A verse says:
The power of vows can universally be the object of cognition, the rest are as explained in the absence of conflict.
The treatise says:
Drawing forth wondrous cognition by making vows first, it is called cognition by vow because it is understood according to the vow.
The intrinsic nature, stage, spiritual lineage, and body of this cognition are the same as those of the absence of conflict, but the object is different, because it takes all dharmas as its object.
How can cognition by vow know the future?
Because it is known by inferring from carefully observing the past and present.
It is like observing crops that are flourishing or weak and inferring that the fields are fertile or poor.
If that is so, why is it called cognition by vow?
Because learners and ordinary beings are also able to know it.
It is not so, because what is known is definite or indefinite.

However, it is said in the scriptures that the great Å›rÄvakas' predictions about future events are indefinite. It is not that there is this erroneous knowledge when they give rise to cognition by vow, because what they predict by observing with other worldly cognition is indefinite.
There is no fault in their predictions being indefinite, because they only observe the beginning and do not observe the end.
For example, when rain falls, before it reaches the ground it is held by Rahula;
when a child is first conceived, it is actually a male, but later it changes and becomes a female;

Or, it is only the knowledge of the aspiration that truly sees the future, but when the preparatory stage is first cultivated, inferential knowledge is first aroused, and by observing the past and present, one infers the future, and then the knowledge of the aspiration is aroused and one is able to truly see.

For this very reason, one is able to know the formless realm. That is to say, first observing the causes and so forth of that realm, inferential knowledge arises, and then the true knowledge of the aspiration is aroused.

Or, observing the mind of death and rebirth in the desire and form realms, one infers and knows the place of rebirth, and then the knowledge of the aspiration is aroused and one is able to truly know.

Then the power of the knowledge of vows should be able to universally cognize the three realms and three times, and should not be inexpressible.
